sections.title: Syntax
sections.raw_content:
An explicitTrueFalseConstant is one of:

  (a) true
  (b) false

sections.title: Example
code:
var found : boolean := false
        for i : 1 .. length (s)
            if s = "." then
                found := true
            end if
        end for
sections.raw_content: The following determines if string s contains a period. After the for statement, found will be true if there is a period in s.
sections.text_content: The following determines if string s contains a period. After the for statement, found will be true if there is a period in s.
sections.mdown_content: The following determines if string *s* contains a period. After the **for** statement, *found* will be **true** if there is a period in *s*.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: true/false values are called boolean values. A boolean variable, such as found in the above example, can have a value of either true or false.
sections.text_content: true/false values are called boolean values. A boolean variable, such as found in the above example, can have a value of either true or false.
sections.mdown_content: **true**/**false** values are called *boolean *values. A **boolean** variable, such as *found* in the above example, can have a value of either **true** or **false**.
